title: 'Sell America' has sparked a FOMO-fueled rush to gold and silver among everyday investors
summary:
Dhalech said he had around $10,000 in physical gold and silver and $11,000 invested in gold ETFs.
He finally began purchasing metals during the pandemic, after his client, a CEO of a precious metals firm, encouraged him to do so.
He told Business Insider he had around $20,000 in physical gold and silver and around $15,000 invested in gold and silver ETFs as of last week.
He sees gold and silver as a form of "wealth preservation" and acknowledges that "Sell America" is one reason so many investors jumped into metals.
Sell America and FOMOCHAIDEER MAHYUDDIN / AFP via Getty ImagesThe craze for metals comes in two flavors.

title: Inflation rises as expected in November: PCE data
summary:
Let's send it over to Yahoo Finance's Fed correspondent Jennifer Schonberger to break down the Fed's preferred inflation gauge.
Personal consumption expenditures index on a core basis, clocking in year-over-year at 2.8%, month over month up two-10ths of a percent.
00:51 Jennifer SchonbergerSo, we should probably take this with a little bit of a grain of salt as we did for other data measures for October and November previously.
Having said that, 2.8%, it's uh closer to 3% than the Fed's 2% inflation goal and sitting right where it was at the beginning of the fall in September.
01:10 Jennifer SchonbergerSo, this certainly doesn't change the course for the Fed's meeting next Wednesday.

title: Gold price nears $5,000 as geopolitical worries linger
summary:
Gold prices rose on Friday morning, advancing closer to the $5,000 mark, as geopolitical concerns remained in focus for investors.
Gold futures (GC=F) were up 0.6% to $4,940.20 per ounce at the time of writing, while spot gold climbed 0.5% at $4,911.19.
Oil prices rose on Friday morning, as Trump's latest comments on Iran fuelled concerns about the potential of tighter supply.
The president said that the US was moving ships toward Iran “just in case” he wants to take action.
That move was reinforced by Saudi Aramco pushing back against fears of a global oil glut, pointing to strong demand."

title: How Debt Bankrupted the British Empire — And Why America, the Second Rome, Is Walking the Same Path
summary:
When viewed alongside the deeper historical pattern of Rome’s decline, the trajectory of the United States becomes less exceptional and more familiar.
The United States rejected it.
The United States now shows early but unmistakable signs of the same trajectory.
The episode did lasting damage because it confirmed what allies already fear: deals with the United States under Trump carry no permanence.
As with late Rome, power remains immense, but it is constrained by financial reality.

title: JD Vance comes up with a new metaphor for the Trump-led economy: The Titanic
summary:
“The ship of state is an ocean liner, it’s not a speed boat,” the president said.
Seventeen years later, JD Vance embraced an almost identical metaphor, except the vice president didn’t refer to just any generic ocean liner — the Ohio Republican had a specific ocean liner in mind.
Vance on the economy:"You don't turn the Titanic around overnight" — FactPost (@factpostnews.bsky.social) 2026-01-22T15:15:28.625879841Z“The Democrats talk a lot about the affordability crisis in the United States of America.
First, as Vance sees it, the United States as led by Donald Trump is the Titanic — a ship once thought to be unsinkable, before those at its helm made catastrophic misjudgments.
(I don’t want to spoil the story for the vice president, but things didn’t work out well for the boat after an unfortunate confrontation with an iceberg.)

title: Report warns nearly half of all car buyers put off by newly proposed 'per-mile' tax: 'Incoherent and inconsistent'
summary:
British motorists are facing a significant barrier to switching to electric vehicles, according to The Times.
Part of the issue is that the U.K.'s EV transition has been so successful.
Electric vehicles are cheaper to run than gas cars, making the switch a major cost-of-living improvement.
"We need more carrot and less stick if we're serious about the electric transition," said Ian Plummer, Autotrader's Chief Customer Officer.
"Drivers respond to incentives, and anything that puts up running costs for electric vehicles will slow that momentum.
